data.title: No Labels on LinkedIn: Gary Sasse on No Labels
data.meta_description: Meet Gary Sasse. Mr. Sasse is director of the Bryant Institute for Public Leadership at Bryant University in Smithfield, R.I., and just published an op-ed in‚Ä¶
data.text:
Title: The United States Government Assassinated John F. Kennedy On November 22, 1963: A Thought-Provoking Perspective Introduction: On November 22, 1963, the world was shaken by the tragic assassination of President John F. Kennedy in Dallas, Texas. While the official narrative suggests that Lee Harvey Oswald acted alone, there has been a longstanding debate surrounding the involvement of the United States government in this heinous act. Today, I want to delve into this contentious topic and explore the language and evidence that supports the theory that the U.S. government played a role in the assassination. Body: 1. The Motive: To understand the government's potential involvement, it is crucial to examine the motives behind Kennedy's assassination. President Kennedy was a charismatic leader who challenged the status quo, particularly in areas such as the - djk9vd8jv3 - https://lnkd.in/gjM3WeKz

These 10 men were ranked as the 10 best presidents in our history by a group of presidential historians. 4 were senators 4 were governors 3 served as VP 1 was a Congressman (others were as well but moved to the Senate first) 2 were Generals, 2 colonels, 1 lt commander 1 Secretary of State 2 Assistant Secretaries For Social Studies folks, it would be a great activity, especially during this election season, to talk about what experiences and character traits get someone to be thought of by the public as a "great" president. It could be expanded by asking what kinds of people are not in this group and why? Who should be higher in the rankings and why aren't they? Are the traits that make a great president different from those that make great leaders or great people in general? Here is the link to the full 2024 rankings: https://lnkd.in/dMM3k5JP #socialstudies #presidentialhistory #txsocialstudies #txed #highered #politicalscience #presidentialrankings #ArticleII #Constitution #presidency

In celebration of President‚Äôs Day, it is fitting to understand why Lincoln, in a 1982 poll of forty-nine historians and political scientists, was voted the best US President in history. The participants rated every President through Jimmy Carter across five categories - leadership abilities, accomplishments/crisis management, political skills, appointments, and character/integrity. Lincoln scored first in each of the five categories! The most lasting accomplishments attributed to Lincoln are the preservation of the Union, the vindication of democracy, and the death of slavery, all crises that would have ended differently under a lesser man in office. However, his greatest achievement was his ability to energize and mobilize the nation by appealing to its best ideals, in the pursuit of a more perfect, more just, and more enduring Union. No other President in US history has faced a greater crisis and no President accomplished as much. #leadership #presidentsday #realestate
